questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and weakness. On evaluation, CBC reveals low hemoglobin and reduced reticulocyte count. His WBC and platelet count were normal. BM examination reveals selective reduction in the erythroid precursors. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Red cell aplasia 

 

Explanation:

 

This patient's presentation is classic for red cell aplasia. Think about what's happening here - the patient has anemia (shown by fatigue, pallor, weakness, and low hemoglobin), but interestingly, only the red blood cell line is affected. The white cells and platelets are completely normal.

 

The hallmark of red cell aplasia is that there is a selective reduction in erythroid precursors. The reduced reticulocyte count is also important as it tell us that the bone marrow isn't even trying to compensate for the anemia

 

Red cell aplasia can happen for several reasons - parvovirus B19 infection, certain medications, autoimmune disorders, or sometimes associated with thymomas. 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Aplastic anaemia If this were aplastic anemia, our patient would be having pancytopenia (low counts across all cell types). Our patient's normal WBC and platelets immediately rule this out.
  • Option C: Iron deficiency anemia; in IDA, the body typically responds by pumping out more reticulocytes to try to compensate. Our patient has reduced Reticulocyte count ruling this out. 
  • Option D: Hemolytic anemia would show increased red cell precursors leading to high reticulocyte count.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This question tests knowledge of the differential diagnosis of anemia based on bone marrow findings and cellular indices. Specifically, it assesses the ability to recognize the characteristic pattern of red cell aplasia: selective reduction of erythroid precursors with normal myeloid and megakaryocytic lines, accompanied by anemia and low reticulocyte count. The key distinguishing feature is the selective involvement of only the red cell line, differentiating it from other anemias that show different patterns of cell production or destruction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NRG-1

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are mesenchymal tumors that commonly present with gastrointestinal bleeding. They are characterized by mutations that lead to the overactivity of tyrosine kinase. The most common mutation associated with GISTs is in the CKIT gene, which leads to the activation of the KIT receptor tyrosine kinase.

 

NRG-1 (Neuregulin 1):

 

NRG-1 is a gene that is part of the epidermal growth factor receptor family. It is not associated with GISTs. Instead, NRG-1 is implicated in the pathogenesis of mental health disorders, such as schizophrenia. Therefore, it is not used as a marker for GISTs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. KIT: KIT mutations are the most common genetic alterations found in GISTs and are critical for the diagnosis and treatment of these tumors.

 

Option B. PDGFR: Mutations in the PDGFR gene occur in a subset of GISTs and play a role similar to KIT mutations in tumor development.

 

Option C. SDH: SDH mutations are linked to Carney-Stratakis syndrome and are significant markers in a subset of GISTs. These mutations lead to defects in cellular respiration and are associated with the development of GISTs and paragangliomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NRG-1 is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors. The primary markers for GISTs include KIT, PDGFR, and SDH mutations.

questions.text: A patient came with the symptoms of drooping of eyelid, difficulty in chewing, weakness in the hands which increases as the day progresses. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia Gravis

 

Myasthenia Gravis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by weakness and rapid fatigue of any of the muscles under voluntary control. It is caused by a breakdown in the normal communication between nerves and muscles. The symptoms of Myasthenia Gravis, such as ptosis (drooping of the eyelid), difficulty in chewing, and progressive weakness in the hands that worsens as the day progresses, match the description given in the question. This condition is known for the decremental response upon repeated stimulation, meaning muscle strength decreases with continued use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lambert Eaton syndrome: This syndrome is also a disorder of the neuromuscular junction but it typically presents with muscle weakness that improves with continued use (incremental response), opposite to Myasthenia Gravis. Hence, the symptom progression described in the question does not fit Lambert Eaton syndrome.

 

Option C. Botulinum toxicity: Botulinum toxin causes muscle paralysis by preventing the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. While it can cause muscle weakness, it does not typically present with the progressive worsening throughout the day as seen in Myasthenia Gravis.

 

Option D. Tetanus toxicity: Tetanus is caused by a toxin produced by the bacterium Clostridium tetani. It leads to muscle stiffness and spasms, not the progressive muscle weakness described in the question. Tetanus usually follows an injury such as a thorn prick, leading to muscle rigidity rather than the fluctuating weakness seen in Myasthenia Gravis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by symptoms such as drooping of the eyelids, difficulty in chewing, and progressive muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest, showing a decremental response upon repeated stimulation.

choices.text: Imprisonment for one year and/or a fine of Rs. 1000
Imprisonment for two years and/or a fine of Rs. 5000
Imprisonment for 1 month and/or a fine of Rs. 500

questions.text: A person "X" strikes another individual "Y" with a wooden stick after being provoked, resulting in a bruise measuring 3x3 cm on the forearm. No additional injuries are observed. Which of the following statements accurately reflects the potential punishment? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Imprisonment for 1 month and/or a fine of Rs. 500

 

Explanation:

 

The situation described involves a case of simple hurt. Person X has caused a 3×3 cm bruise on Y's forearm with a wooden stick after provocation, with no additional injuries. This constitutes a case of simple hurt under Section 323 IPC, which specifies imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Imprisonment for one year and/or a fine of Rs. 1000 This punishment is excessive for simple hurt. This level of punishment would typically be associated with more serious offenses or aggravated forms of hurt.

 

Option B: Imprisonment for two years and/or a fine of Rs. 5000 This punishment is significantly excessive for simple hurt. This would be more appropriate for grievous hurt under Section 325 IPC, but the described injury (single bruise) does not qualify as grievous hurt.

 

Option D: Rigorous Imprisonment for six months the punishment is disproportionate to the offense described. Rigorous imprisonment for six months would be applicable for more serious offenses, not for causing a simple bruise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The above question is as per old laws. It is not applicable as per new laws.

questions.text: Which of the following neurons predominantly fire during forceful expiration?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ventral group of neurons

 

Ventral respiratory group of neurons, are located on each side of medulla found in the nucleus ambigus rostrally and the nucleus retroambigus caudally.

 

The function of this neuronal group differs from dorsal group by -

 

  1. The neurons of the ventral respiratory group remain almost totally inactive during normal quiet respiration.
  2. Does not participate in the basic rhythmical oscillation that controls respiration
  3. When the respiratory drive for increased pulmonary ventilation becomes greater than normal, respiratory signals spill over into the ventral respiratory neurons from the basic oscillating mechanism of the dorsal respiratory area
  4. Electrical stimulation of a few of the neurons in the ventral group causes inspiration, whereas stimulation of others causes expiration. Therefore, these neurons contribute to both inspiration and expiration. They are especially important in providing the powerful expiratory signals to the abdominal muscles during very heavy expiration. Thus, this area operates more or less as an overdrive mechanism when high levels of pulmonary ventilation are required, especially during heavy exercise.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dorsal group of neurons: Incorrect because the DRG is mainly active during quiet breathing and primarily controls inspiration.

 

Option C. Pneumotaxic center: Incorrect as the pneumotaxic center primarily modulates the switch between inhalation and exhalation to control the rate and pattern of breathing, rather than directly causing forceful expiration.

 

Option D. Chemoreceptors: Incorrect because chemoreceptors detect changes in the chemical composition of the blood (like CO2 and O2 levels) and influence the respiratory centers indirectly rather than actively firing during respiratory movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ventral Respiratory Group of neurons, particularly some subsets within this group, are actively involved in generating the neural signals required for forceful expiration, making them essential during increased respiratory demands such as during intense physical activity.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with obstructed labor and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

  • Obstructed labor is a direct indication for an emergency cesarean section
  • Obstructed labor happens when despite good uterine contractions, labor does not progress due to problems in the maternal pelvis/ fetus or a mechanical obstruction
  • Features of Obstructed Labor:
  • Maternal exhaustion and dehydration
  • Abdominal examination
    • Upper segment is tonically contracted with no relaxation The wall becomes thicker
    • Lower segment becomes distended and thinned out
    • Fetal parts not easily felt
    • Round ligaments taut and tender
    • Bandl’s ring is felt (Retraction ring)
    • Fetal heart rate absent
  • Vaginal exam
    • Vagina feels hot and dry
    • Cervix hangs loosely like a curtain
    • Caput +++
    • Moulding +++
    • Head feels jammed in the pelvis
  • The mainstay of management will be to start IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Emergency LSCS is the rule in Obstructed labor even in a dead fetus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Craniotomy: This is a destructive fetal operation which is not preferred anymore even in a non-viable fetus/ dead fetus. It can be done if ffacilities for immediate cesarean are not available.  The main indications for fetal craniotomy are:

 

  • Cephalic presentation with obstructed labour
  • Hydrocephalus in a living fetus
  • Interlocking head of twins
  • Aftercoming head of breech

 

Option B. Decapitation: It is severing of the fetal head from the trunk. It is a destructive operation and again is not preferred unless facilities for emergency LSCS are not available or in exceptional circumstances. Indications are

 

  • Neglected shoulder with a dead fetus
  • Locked twins

 

Option D. Forceps extraction: Instrumental delivery is contra-indicated in obstructed labor. CPD should be ruled out prior to applying an instrument (Forceps or vacuum)

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of obstructed labor, an emergency cesarean section is the recommended management, even if the fetus is deceased.

 

Ref: Page no 421, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: Which of the following structures is contained within the femoral canal? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Lymph node of Cloquet

 

The femoral canal is the medial compartment of the femoral sheath, which is a funnel-shaped sleeve of fascia enclosing the upper 3-4 cm of the femoral vessels. The femoral canal contains a lymph node of Cloquet or Rosenmüller, lymphatics, and a small amount of areolar tissue. This lymph node drains the glans penis in males and the clitoris in females. The femoral canal is about 1.5 cm long and about 1.5 cm wide at its base, with its upper end called the femoral ring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral artery - This is incorrect because the femoral artery is contained in the lateral compartment of the femoral sheath, not the femoral canal.

 

Option C. Femoral vein - This is incorrect because the femoral vein is contained in the intermediate compartment of the femoral sheath, not the femoral canal.

 

Option D. Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve - This is incorrect because this nerve occupies the lateral compartment of the femoral sheath along with the femoral artery, not the femoral canal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The femoral canal is the medial compartment of the femoral sheath containing the lymph node of Cloquet (Rosenmüller), lymphatics, and areolar tissue, making it a potential site for femoral hernia development, especially in females due to their wider pelvis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia that is more pronounced for liquids than solids. He reports occasional regurgitation of undigested food and has significant weight loss over the past few months. A barium swallow study is performed. Which radiological sign is most likely to be observed? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rat-tail sign

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests achalasia cardia, a primary motility disorder of the esophagus. 

 

  • Dysphagia more pronounced for liquids than solids (characteristic of achalasia)
  • The pattern is explained by the pathophysiology: liquids lack the mass and gravity effect to push through the non-relaxing lower esophageal sphincter, while solids can generate more pressure to pass through
  • Regurgitation of undigested food
  • Weight loss due to feeding difficulties 
  • The bird beak sign, showing a smooth, symmetrical tapering of the distal esophagus, is the classic radiological finding in achalasia on barium swallow. 
  • The rat tail sign, often used for carcinoma esophagus has also been described for achalasia. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corkscrew esophagus: This appearance is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm, a different motility disorder with intermittent dysphagia.

 

Option B. Apple-core lesion: This is typically seen in colonic carcinoma, appearing as a symmetric narrowing with overhanging edges. It's not associated with esophageal disorders.

 

Option C. String sign: This is typically seen in CHPS in the pylorus and TB and Chron’s disease in the ileum and represents narrowing. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In achalasia, dysphagia is characteristically worse for liquids than solids due to the underlying motility disorder affecting lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, with bird beak sign and rat tail sign being the characteristic radiological finding on barium swallow.

questions.text:
The fibres of the internal oblique muscle and transversus abdominus muscle contribute to which boundaries of the inguinal canal walls? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Anterior wall
  2. Roof
  3. Floor
  4. Posterior wall
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ii and iv

 

 

 

The inguinal canal is an important structure in the anterior abdominal wall, with specific boundaries formed by different layers of muscles and fascia. The internal oblique is present in the lateral 1/3rd of anterior wall but transverse abdominis does not contribute to the anterior wall at all.

 

ii. Roof: The fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, along with their conjoint tendon, form the roof of the inguinal canal.

 

iv. Posterior wall: The conjoint tendon, formed by the joining of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, also contributes to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

i. Anterior wall: The anterior wall of the inguinal canal is primarily formed by the external oblique aponeurosis, along with skin and superficial fascia. The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles do not contribute to the anterior wall.

 

iii. Floor: The floor of the inguinal canal is formed by the inguinal ligament, not by the internal oblique or transversus abdominis muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles contribute to the roof and posterior wall of the inguinal canal through their conjoint tendon.

questions.text:
You are employed at a primary health center (PHC) located in an area with a high risk of earthquakes. What actions would you take to ensure readiness for potential emergencies? [NEET PG 2022]

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Follow instructions given over the phone or radio by higher officials
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1,2,3

 

To ensure readiness for potential emergencies in a high-risk earthquake area, the following actions are crucial:

 

  1. Disaster Preparedness: Ensuring all financial and other resources are available. This involves mobilizing funds and resources for quick evacuation and emergency response.
  2. Increase Public Awareness: Conducting campaigns and using loudspeakers to inform the public about earthquake preparedness measures and safety protocols.
  3. Conduct a Simulation: Performing disaster simulations and assessing the response to identify areas for improvement and ensure the effectiveness of the emergency plan.

 

These steps are essential components of a comprehensive disaster preparedness strategy and done by someone working in a PHC situated in a high seismic zone. A medical officer is supposed to provide instructions by any communication method possible to manage through the calamity.

 

Roles and responsibilities of medical officer of PHC when posted in Seismic areas

 

  • Ensure funds and resources are available and can be mobilized at the time of disaster for quick evacuation
  • Preparedness to handle emergency
  • Disaster simulation practices and then check the response

 

Other Options:

 

While following instructions from higher officials is important during an actual disaster, it is not a proactive preparedness measure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency preparedness is a programme of long-term development activities whose goals are to strengthen the overall capacity and capability of a country to manage efficiently all types of emergency. It involves the following steps:

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Evaluate the risk of disaster
  5. Information sessions coordination with news media
  6. Adopt standards and regulations

questions.text: The classic Unhappy Triad (O' Donoghue's Triad) involves injuries to all of the following structures, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL)

 

O'Donoghue's Triad, also known as the "Unhappy Triad," consists of three specific knee structures that are commonly injured together in sports: the Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL), Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL), and Medial Meniscus. The PCL is not part of this classic injury pattern. This triad typically occurs when a valgus force is applied to the knee while it's in a flexed position with external rotation, commonly during contact sports.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial Meniscus - This is incorrect because the medial meniscus is actually part of O'Donoghue's Triad. It is often damaged alongside the ACL and MCL when the knee experiences a valgus force with rotation.

 

Option B. Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) - This is incorrect because the ACL is an essential component of O'Donoghue's Triad. It prevents anterior translation of the tibia and is commonly torn in this injury pattern.

 

Option C. Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL) - This is incorrect because the MCL is a key component of O'Donoghue's Triad. It resists valgus forces at the knee joint and is typically the first structure damaged in this injury pattern.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

O'Donoghue's Triad consists of injuries to the ACL, MCL, and medial meniscus (often remembered as MAM), while the PCL is not included in this classic injury pattern.

questions.text: Match the following cancers with their respective genes involved: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B

 

1. KIT (D): Commonly mutated in Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GISTs), where it plays a critical role in tumor growth and survival.

 

2. K-RAS (C): Frequently mutated in pancreatic cancers, contributing to the cancerous cells’ growth and division.

 

3. JAK 2 (A): Mutations in JAK 2 are associated with various types of myeloproliferative neoplasms, affecting blood cell production.

 

4. ALK (B): ALK gene rearrangements are a key driver in a subset of non-small cell lung cancers, particularly adenocarcinoma, leading to targeted treatment approaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adenocarcinoma lung: Associated with mutations or rearrangements in ALK, making ALK inhibitors a treatment option.
  • Myeloproliferative neoplasm: JAK 2 mutations enhance the understanding and treatment of these diseases.
  • Pancreatic Carcinoma: Known for K-RAS mutations which are pivotal in the development and progression of pancreatic cancer.

choices.text: Asphyxia
Vagal inhibition
Laryngospasm
Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: An Autopsy was conducted on a male with history of drowning. However, no water was found in his lungs, and he was determined to have experienced ‘dry drowning’. What is the cause of death: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Laryngospasm

 

Option C. Laryngospasm : In cases of dry drowning, laryngospasm is a reflex closure of the vocal cords and other airway muscles that occurs when water touches the vocal cords or throat. This spasm can seal the airway, preventing water from entering the lungs but also air, leading to suffocation.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Asphyxia : In typical drowning cases, this happens when water fills the lungs, preventing oxygen from reaching the blood. However, it isn't the direct cause in dry drowning.

 

Option B. Vagal Inhibition : This refers to a sudden stop of the heart due to a reflex action stimulated by extreme stress or shock, particularly cold water impacting the face. It can instantly stop heart activity but is rare.

 

Option D. Ventricular Fibrillation : Ventricular fibrillation is a severe cardiac rhythm disturbance where the heart's electrical activity becomes so chaotic that the heart stops pumping effectively, leading to sudden cardiac death. It can happen due to severe hypoxia from drowning.

 

Educational objective:

 

Dry drowning is characterized by a laryngospasm that prevents water from entering the lungs but leads to death through asphyxia due to a blocked airway.

choices.text: It is the most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children.
Initial management typically involves prednisolone at 60 mg/day.
Remission is indicated by a urine protein: creatinine ratio >2.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is INCORRECT? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Remission is indicated by a urine protein: creatinine ratio >2.

 

Remission in minimal change disease is indicated by a urine protein: creatinine ratio <0.2 (not >2). Remission is defined as "urine albumin nil or trace (or proteinuria <4 mg/m²/hr) for 3 consecutive early morning specimens." A protein ratio >2 would actually indicate heavy proteinuria of nephrotic range proteinuria, not remission.

 

Remission criteria are specifically defined as early morning urine showing protein nil/trace for 3 consecutive days or proteinuria <4 mg/m²/hr. A ratio >2 would indicate ongoing disease activity rather than resolution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimal change disease (MCD) is indeed the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, accounting for approximately 90% of cases of idiopathic nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option B. The prognosis of minimal change disease is generally good, with >95% of patients responding to steroid therapy. Most patients outgrow the condition by adulthood.

 

Option C. Initial management involves prednisolone at a dose of 2 mg/kg/day (maximum 60 mg) for 6 weeks followed by alternate day therapy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Remission in nephrotic syndrome is defined by the absence of proteinuria (nil/trace) for 3 consecutive days or proteinuria <4 mg/m²/hr, while a urine protein ratio >2 indicates ongoing heavy proteinuria, not remission.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient complained of bilateral lower limb numbness. He has a history of low BP and gastrectomy done for gastric cancer a year back. On examination, Romberg test is positive and there is loss of proprioception in both lower limbs. Which of the following deficiency can cause this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

This patient's presentation strongly suggests Vitamin B12 deficiency for several reasons:

 

  1. History of gastrectomy – Loss of stomach leads to loss of intrinsic factor, essential for B12 absorption
  2. Neurological symptoms – Bilateral lower limb numbness
  3. Positive Romberg test and loss of proprioception indicate posterior column involvement, which is characteristic of subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord seen in B12 deficiency
  4. The combination of gastrectomy and neurological symptoms is classic for B12 deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B6 deficiency: While it can cause peripheral neuropathy, it doesn't typically cause posterior column signs

 

Option C. Thiamine deficiency: Primarily causes Wernicke's encephalopathy and cardiovascular symptoms; doesn't typically present with proprioception loss; more commonly seen in alcoholics

 

Option D. Folic acid deficiency: Primarily causes hematological manifestations; does not cause neurological symptoms like B12 deficiency

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrectomy leads to B12 deficiency due to loss of intrinsic factor, and B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, presenting with posterior column signs (proprioception loss and positive Romberg test).

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought with bow legs and on x-ray of wrist, following were the findings. The child also had low serum calcium and low serum phosphate values. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rickets

 

  • Vitamin-D, calcium, and phosphorus are the main factors that influence bone maturation and mineralization. 
  • Defective mineralization can lead to rickets and/or osteomalacia. 
  • Rickets is characterized by a defect in mineralization and the widening of the epiphyseal plates.
  • Rickets occurs exclusively in children.
  • Nutritional rickets is the most common cause of bone disease.
  • Vitamin D deficiency is the most common cause of nutritional rickets.
  • Any defect in osteoid mineralization may cause rickets.
  • In all types of rickets, the characteristic features occur at the growth plate. 
  • In rickets, the calcium level is either normal or low; phosphate levels are low; and ALP and PTH are high.
  • The potential lower limb deformities include bow legs (genu varus), knock knees (genu valgus), and joints (knees and ankles) swelling, whereas the deformities of the upper limbs include the wrist widening.
  • The ulna grows relatively rapidly and hence, it is significantly affected.
  • The characteristic radiographic features of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis), indistinct and hazy metaphysis that is abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance), bowing of diaphysis with thinning of cortices.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scurvy: Scurvy is a condition caused by dietary lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), hence is also called hypovitaminosis C. It is characterized by an increased bleeding tendency, impaired collagen synthesis resulting in osteoporosis, and impaired wound healing. It is rarely seen in adults. Young children and elderly are more predisposed to scurvy due to diet or overheating of food. It does not occur before 6 months of age. Patients present with lethargy, malaise, bone pain, bleeding diathesis, and impaired wound healing. Pediatric radiographic features include generalized osteopenia, cortical thinning (pencil-point cortex), periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage, expansion of costochondral junctions (scorbutic rosary), hemarthrosis, Wimberger ring sign (circular, opaque shadow around epiphyseal centers of ossification, due to bleeding). 

 

 

Option C. Hypophosphatemia: Hypophosphatemia is defined as an adult serum phosphate level < 2.5 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL). Normal serum phosphate levels in children are considerably higher, 4-7 mg/dL. Hypophosphatemia is a relatively common laboratory abnormality and is often an incidental finding. Most patients with hypophosphatemia are asymptomatic, and the most common symptom is generalized mild to moderate weakness. Clinical symptoms usually appear with moderate or severe hypophosphatemia. Neurologic symptoms include altered mental status, dysarthria, seizures, and numbness or reflexive weakness. Cardiac and respiratory failure can occur in severe cases. In addition to muscle weakness, muscle pain may signify hypophosphatemia-related rhabdomyolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image of the child’s hands and wrists shows cupping and splaying of the radius and the ulna. 
  • The patient presents with bow legs, and decreased levels of serum calcium and phosphate. 
  • These are common findings of rickets caused by defective bone mineralization or nutritional deficiency of vitamin D in children.

choices.text: They act on extracellular receptors only
It transmits impulses from cytoplasm to nuclear receptor
Act both on intracellular and extracellular receptors

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct regarding the secondary messenger? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mediate intracellular hormone response

 

Secondary messengers are molecules that relay signals received at receptors on the cell surface to target molecules inside the cell. When a hormone binds to its extracellular receptor, it triggers the production of secondary messengers inside the cell. These secondary messengers, such as cyclic AMP (cAMP), inositol triphosphate (IP3), and calcium ions, then activate protein kinases and other enzymes, leading to an intracellular response. This process is crucial for the amplification of the signal and the initiation of specific cellular activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They act on extracellular receptors only: This is incorrect. Secondary messengers do not act on receptors; they are produced inside the cell after the hormone binds to an extracellular receptor.

 

Option B. It transmits impulses from cytoplasm to nuclear receptor: This is incorrect. Secondary messengers activate protein kinases that may eventually affect nuclear processes, but the secondary messengers themselves do not directly transmit impulses to nuclear receptors.

 

Option D. Act both on intracellular and extracellular receptors: This is incorrect. Secondary messengers act within the cell and do not interact with extracellular receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary messengers mediate intracellular hormone responses by transmitting signals from cell surface receptors to target molecules within the cell, leading to a specific cellular response.

choices.text: Emergency cesarean facility should be there

questions.text: Correct about trial of labor in a previous LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section) is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency cesarean facility should be there

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is emergency cesarean facility should be there. When considering a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), it is crucial to ensure that the facility is equipped to handle an emergency cesarean section. This is because the risk of complications, including uterine rupture, can pose significant risks to both the mother and the fetus.

 

Emergency cesarean facility: The availability of an emergency cesarean section facility is essential for any patient undergoing TOLAC. This ensures that if complications arise, such as uterine rupture, immediate surgical intervention can be provided to minimize risks.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Risk of uterine rupture is 4-9%: This statement is incorrect for a lower segment cesarean section. The risk of uterine rupture in a TOLAC for a lower segment cesarean section is much lower, around 0.2%. The 4-9% risk applies to upper segment or classical cesarean sections.

 

Additional Considerations for TOLAC:

 

  1. Interval between pregnancies: The inter-delivery interval should be more than 18 months to allow adequate healing of the uterine scar.
  2. Reason for previous cesarean: Conditions like cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) or other recurrent indications may reduce the likelihood of a successful TOLAC and increase the risk of complications.
  3. Monitoring: Continuous fetal monitoring during labor is recommended to detect any signs of fetal distress early.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When attempting a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), ensure that an emergency cesarean facility is available to handle any complications, particularly the risk of uterine rupture.

choices.text: Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Years lost due to premature death

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL)

 

Definition: YPLL is based on Years of life lost through premature death

 

Importance:

 

  • YPLL occurs before the age to which a dying person could have expected to survive
  • YPLL is a type of mortality indicator

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Years lost to morbidity refers to the time spent living with a disease or disability, which is not directly related to the concept of years of potential life lost.

 

Option C. Years lost to disability is a component of disability-adjusted life years (DALY). DALY Is BEST measure of burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.

 

DALY = YLL (Years of lost life) + YLD (Years lost to disability)

 

Option D. life would account into QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years)

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a measure that quantifies the impact of premature death on a population by calculating the number of years not lived by individuals who die before reaching a specified age. It highlights the significance of early mortality and its impact on society.

questions.text: What is the rate of increment of head circumference in the first three months of life?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 cm per month

 

During the first three months of life, the head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month. This rapid growth is due to the significant brain development occurring during this period. After the first three months, the growth rate slows down. From three to six months of age, the head circumference increases by about 1 cm per month, and from six months to one year, it increases by about 0.5 cm per month.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month during the first three months of life.

questions.text: Which antibodies are characterized against Mucocutaneous Pemphigus Vulgaris? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Desmoglein 1 and 3.

 

  • Mucocutaneous Pemphigus Vulgaris is characterized by antibodies against both Desmoglein 1 and Desmoglein 3. 

 

 

  • In Pemphigus vulgaris, the target antigens are "Desmoglein-3 > 1," which means both are involved but Desmoglein-3 is predominant. 
  • While mucosal-dominant PV has antibodies primarily against Desmoglein 3, mucocutaneous PV (affecting both skin and mucosa) requires antibodies to both Desmoglein 1 and 3. 
  • The presence of both antibodies explains the development of skin lesions in addition to oral involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desmoglein 1: 

 

  • This is primarily the target antigen in Pemphigus foliaceus. When only anti-Dsg1 antibodies are present, they cause skin lesions without mucosal involvement. 
  • Isolated anti-Dsg1 antibodies cannot explain the mucocutaneous manifestation of PV.

 

Option B. Desmoglein 3: 

 

  • While anti-Dsg3 antibodies are predominant in Pemphigus vulgaris, having only anti-Dsg3 antibodies typically results in mucosal-dominant disease. 
  • Mucocutaneous PV requires both anti-Dsg1 and anti-Dsg3 antibodies.

 

Option D. None: 

 

  • Incorrect as Pemphigus vulgaris definitely has autoantibodies against desmogleins. The absence of anti-desmoglein antibodies would be inconsistent with the diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mucocutaneous Pemphigus vulgaris requires antibodies against both Desmoglein 1 and 3, with Desmoglein-3 antibodies typically being predominant; this combined antibody profile explains the involvement of both skin and mucous membranes.

questions.text: All are hereditary causes of thrombosis except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PNH (Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria)

 

PNH is an acquired stem cell disorder, not a hereditary condition. It occurs due to a somatic mutation in the PIG-A gene that produces GPI (glycosyl phosphatidylinositol) anchors. This defect affects proteins CD55 and CD59 (also known as DAF and MIRL respectively), which are important complement regulatory proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein C deficiency: Hereditary cause of thrombosis; Protein C is a natural anticoagulant

 

Option C. Factor V Leiden mutation: Most common inherited cause of thrombophilia

 

Option D. Antithrombin III deficiency: Inherited condition increasing thrombotic risk

 

Educational Objective:

 

PNH is an acquired (not hereditary) stem cell disorder caused by somatic mutations in the PIG-A gene. Protein C deficiency, Factor V Leiden mutation, and Antithrombin III deficiency are hereditary causes of thrombophilia.

questions.text: Which of the following tumors arises from the olfactory nasal mucosa? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Esthesioneuroblastoma

 

Explanation:


Esthesioneuroblastoma, also called olfactory neuroblastoma, specifically arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of the nasal cavity. It is also known as olfactory placode tumor, highlighting its origin from the specialized olfactory mucosa. This tumor typically presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis, and can invade surrounding structures including the orbit and intracranial cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal Glioma: This is a congenital lesion that represents entrapped neural tissue during embryonic development. It doesn't arise from the olfactory mucosa but is a developmental anomaly. Nasal gliomas are typically seen in infants and children and may be extranasal (60%), intranasal (30%) or both (10%).

 

Option B. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: This tumor arises from the glands of the mucous membrane or minor salivary glands, rather than from the olfactory epithelium. It typically involves the upper part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity but is not derived from olfactory tissue.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: This tumor originates from the epithelial lining of the nasopharynx, not from the olfactory mucosa in the nasal cavity. It arises from a completely different anatomical site.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Esthesioneuroblastoma is a distinctive neoplasm that uniquely originates from the specialized olfactory epithelium in the upper nasal cavity, making it the only true tumor of olfactory mucosal origin among the options provided.

questions.text: For OME, Myringotomy is done in which quadrant? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antero-inferior

 

Explanation:

 

In Otitis Media with Effusion (OME), myringotomy is performed in the antero-inferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane. This location is specifically chosen because it provides optimal drainage while avoiding important structures. The antero-inferior quadrant is the safest area to make an incision as it avoids damage to the ossicles and other vital middle ear structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antero-posterior: No such quadrant exists.

 

Option C. Postero-superior: This is the most dangerous quadrant for myringotomy as it contains the incus and stapes. Additionally, the chorda tympani nerve runs through this area, and facial nerve injury is a risk if the incision extends too deeply. This area is avoided for routine myringotomy.

 

Option D. Postero-inferior: Although this quadrant is relatively safe compared to the postero-superior quadrant, it is not the preferred site for myringotomy. The round window niche is located in the posterior part of the middle ear, and damage to this structure could potentially affect inner ear function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringotomy for OME is performed in the antero-inferior quadrant because it provides optimal drainage while avoiding vital middle ear structures, ensuring both effectiveness and safety of the procedure.

questions.text: After a myocardial infarction (MI), staining was done using Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) Most myocardial tissue got stained in brick red color, while some tissue remained pale. What is the minimum survival time required post MI for this color change to appear? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2-3 hours

 

Explanation:

 

The Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) test is used to detect early myocardial infarction (MI) by staining viable cardiac tissue.

 

  • The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 12 hours for any  gross changes in the heart to be visible.
  • The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 6 hours for any  microscopic changes in the heart to be visible.

 

However, with the use of TTC staining, gross changes in the heart can be observed as early as 2-3 hours post-MI.

 

  • In normal tissue, mitochondrial enzymes such as dehydrogenases are present, which reduce TTC, resulting in a brick-red color.
  • In infarcted tissue, the infarcted area remains pale due to the absence of these mitochondrial enzymes, which are affected by the lack of blood supply.
  • Complete mitochondrial enzyme death typically requires at least 2-3 hours of survival time, post-MI.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. 1 hour: Incorrect. The TTC reaction typically requires at least 2-3 hours of survival time after MI for a clear distinction between infarcted and normal tissue to be visible.

 

Option C. 6-12 hours: Incorrect. While TTC can detect MI after 2-3 hours, the question specifically asks about the minimum time, not a broader window.

 

Option D. > 24 hours: Incorrect. The TTC test can detect MI much earlier than 24 hours. The question is asking about the minimum time needed for the color change to appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The TTC test is used to detect early MI. A brick-red color appears in viable myocardium, while the infarcted area remains pale after 2-3 hours post-MI. 

 

Note that some sources suggest a minimum survival time of 4 hours for TTC positivity instead of 2-3 hours.
